title: Red Army Faction
summary: The Red Army Faction (RAF, German: [ɛʁʔaːˈʔɛf] (listen); German: Rote Armee Fraktion, pronounced [ˌʁoː.tə aʁˈmeː fʁakˌt͡si̯oːn] (listen)),[lower-alpha 1] also known as the Baader–Meinhof Group or Baader–Meinhof Gang (German: Baader-Meinhof-Gruppe, Baader-Meinhof-Bande, German: [ˈbaːdɐ ˈmaɪ̯nˌhɔf ˈɡʁʊpə] (listen)), was a West German far-left militant organization founded in 1970. Key early figures included Andreas Baader, Ulrike Meinhof, Gudrun Ensslin, and Horst Mahler, among others.[lower-alpha 2] The government of the Federal Republic of Germany considered the Red Army Faction to be a terrorist organization.[lower-alpha 3] The group was motivated by leftist political concerns and the perceived failure of their parents' generation to confront Germany's Nazi past[2] and received support from Stasi and other Eastern Bloc security services.[3][4][5]
